awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Tomographic Particle Image Velocimetry System
awd_abstract_narration:
With the Major Research Instrumentation award, Clarkson University will acquire a tomographic particle image velocimetry system.  Acquisition of the instrument will facilitate advancements in scientific research across a diverse range of topics, such as human voice production, modeling and prediction of sediment and debris transport in hydrology and the impact on biodiversity and ecology, and novel approaches for carbon sequestration.  Ensuring broad and equitable access to the system across the entire campus of Clarkson University will place Clarkson at the forefront of fluid dynamics research capabilities and encourage and promote novel cross-disciplinary research endeavors.  Availability of this instrument will afford educational opportunities at both the undergraduate and graduate levels through classroom instruction on the experimental technique, as well as hands-on laboratory training on the practical use of the system.  Clarkson University serves a significant number of students that are underrepresented in STEM fields and that come from lower socioeconomic backgrounds.  Exposure to, and utilization of, this state-of-the-art measurement system will inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers. 

The primary advantage of a tomographic particle image velocimetry system is the ability to simultaneously resolve both the velocity vector and the velocity gradient tensor over all three coordinate directions within a volume. This capability will significantly advance research efforts at Clarkson University in the following specific areas: (1) aero-acoustic sound source identification and fluid-structure interactions in voiced speech production to identify how pathological behaviors impact vocal function, (2) quantification of flow morphologies in rivers arising from ice and debris obstructions with application to mitigating damage arising from flooding events, (3) enhancing ecological function in urban streams through quantification of the physical, biological, and ecologically-relevant sediment transport processes, (4) control of dynamic stall on airfoils to enhance aircraft performance, (5) quantification of multiphase flows through geological fractures to optimize carbon sequestration, (6) drag minimization of juncture flows with application to increasing fuel efficiency in large vehicle transport, and (7) development of a novel technique for estimating pressure fields from experimental velocity fields. It is anticipated that implementing a strategy whereby a percentage of the instrument availability is dedicated to new users, at no cost, will catalyze additional new and exciting cross-disciplinary research efforts across campus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project acquired a tomographic particle image velocimetry (tomo-PIV) system. A tomo-PIV system is capable of measuring all three components of velocity within a prescribed volume. This unique capability provides the ability to understand, and analyze, complex three-dimensional flow dynamics.

The project used the tomo-PIV system to advance both scientific discovery and the education of engineering graduate students in the field of fluid mechanics.

The tomo-PIV system was used in support of two research projects. The first explored the velocity produced at the mouth during voiced speech production. The motivation for this work was to improve understanding of the flow that transports respiratory droplets and aerosols into the surrounding environment, and which is the source of airborne transport of infectious diseases. Specifically, the flow exiting the mouth during the production of fricative consonants (e.g., “f” in Flow and “th” in Throw) was explored as these utterances produce high-velocity jets of air that are believed to transport infectious particles the longest distance. Measurements were performed by measuring the airflow passing through two-dimensional, simplified three-dimensional, and anatomic models of the mouth geometry for the utterances of interest. Results showed that the jet exiting the mouth has a different shape/structure than previous theoretical models had assumed. Instead of being axi-symmetric, it is elliptical in nature. Consequently, the flow patterns that transport potentially infectious particles into the surroundings are different than most models assume. This work has provided an updated understanding of the flow behavior, including recommendations for how models that predict infection risk based on the expiratory flow field during speech can be improved to provide more physically-realistic results.

The second project explored how in stream boulder placement influences ecological function of streams, which is critical for revitalizing the hydrology of urban streams. Common approaches utilize obstacles/boulder placement to influence the local hydraulics, sediment, and habitat. These factors are important for restoring, promoting, and maintaining healthy ecological function as they influence sediment transport processes in the flow, including erosion and deposition. Measurements of the flow field around regularly spaced boulders using the tomo-PIV system in an experimental water channel revealed that these key parameters that influence ecological health in streams are highly dependent upon the specific spacing and arrangement of boulders within the stream.  These findings are critical as they provide practical guidance to restore and improve hydrological function in urban streams.

Because tomo-PIV is an advanced fluid measurement technique that is not widely available within the University setting this project also sought to train both professors and graduate students on the implementation and usage of it. As a result of this project, three professors, one laboratory technician, and eight graduate students were instructed and trained in the proper usage of tomo-PIV to experimentally measure three-dimensional flow fields.

Project outcomes included one journal article that is in review, two conference papers, one technical report, one Ph.D. dissertation, and one invited seminar.
